topic.title: Coppersurfer.tk script: Should I be concerned?
topic.body: If you visit http://coppersurfer.tk ; there's a script on it while examining the page via Firefox's Element Inspecter (right click > Inspect Element (Q)) , but not when you view its source. Given that it's an HTTP connection, my ISP could easily be injecting traffic into the packet. Can anyone confirm this? Script is apparently titled PostRPC, which a quick google gives as Microsoft's Remote Procedure Call. Can post what I see if needed.

topic.title: US House of Representatives to vote on FCC privacy protection rollback 2017-03-28
topic.body:
Fight for the Future blew the whistle that US Congress is going to vote on whether to roll back the FCC's privacy protections, and the ISP industry has enough senators bought to rig the vote. If you are a US citizen, please please PLEASE call your senators RIGHT NOW. The link has phone numbers for those that are sympathetic. If you care at all about an uncomprimised Internet, this is something you need to spread, or the dollar-per-hollar shills will make life that much harder. 

https://www.fightforthefuture.org/news/2017-03-23-congress-votes-today-on-whether-to-gut-the-fccs/

EDIT: Now it has to pass the House of Representatives. Just as a reminder: If the House votes yes, your personal data such as which banks you visit, hospitals and doctors you trust, your worker associations, all of that can and will be inferred from the metadata that the ISPs will be allowed to collect and sell, potentially making you get blackballed from a higher-paying job or targeted for discrimination. PLEASE call your reps and tell them to vote no on the CRA vote on Tuesday.

https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2017/03/we-have-24-hours-save-online-privacy-rules

topic.title: OpenSSL build tutorial
topic.body:
Oh hai ZeroTalk.

I've written a tutorial for building an OpenSSL binary and the required libraries for Android devices; this enables your device to encrypt data on device, prior to sending across the internet. This enables one to, say, encrypt an photo record of some undesirable activity to store safely in a cloud.

For those unfamiliar, [OpenSSL](https://www.openssl.org/) is one implementation of the Secure Sockets Layer standard, which basically enables you to use the un-snoopable HTTPS to connect to websites, keeping sensitive data such as banking information, medical records and queries or career applications from being modified in transit in between you and the bank/hospital/job in question. It is symmetrical encryption, which means that there is one key, unlike your ZeroNet identity keys, which are asymmetrical and have two keys, public and private. The two models provide different advantages and disadvantages, dictating which situations which each are best suited for.

OpenSSL provides the source code for a symmetrical encryption binary, which is what the tutorial details how to create. A prebuilt binary and the required libraries have been provided for ARM-based devices. The tutorial itself can be found [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Bo6oCbFEMhy1ejrehrSTGxiotgDsYCMJq/?Post:6:OpenSSL+for+Android+Build+Tutorial) at my ZeroBlog. Prebuilts, for those inclined, can be found [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Bo6oCbFEMhy1ejrehrSTGxiotgDsYCMJq/loader/index.html?1GV786wK).

Please feel free to comment and question below and at the blog. I'll try to answer to the best of my ability. [ZeroMail](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit/?to=rythyrix) is also accepted.

1_1CoVAt2jBzV4Na6nX3VG1JSfjS8fwse1Z9.body:
> [astzor](#comment_6_1LfQ8dwqkqkGQNCg1kBevHPxjvTRJTQYBz): Check out Play, it hosted on Zeronet

While Play exists, and indeed performs admirably on the UI front with its search engine correlating many, many torrents into one entry, it is currently limited to movies. ZeroTorrent.bit has applications, games, TV shows and music in addition to movies. Thus, depending on what you are wanting to torrent, ZeroTorrent might be a better choice.

Props to Play, however, for sourcing its content from the clearnet, and providing source links. Depends on how used you are to trawling through torrents.

1_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y.body:
> [waterrabbit](#comment_69_1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC): It seems to be calling the GeoLocation API...

Where might I find this Tor Mailing List? Plus, I am using Firefox, not the Tor Browser. I'll see if restarting with addons disabled produces the same result.
@waterrabbit : If you're on the mailing list, you will be receiving the mailing list at your next dump. Thanks for the referral.

The worst part, this is following me around on every HTTP connection I use. Been trying different JS injectors to remove the element, but none of them offer either fine-grained enough filters or an option to inject the removal script prior to the self-deleting script. Any suggestions?

@waterrabbit: I did. Tor Browser didn't show the script, at least not in the element inspector. Free VPNs are a trap and both ```https://phx.sslsecureproxy.com``` and ```https://www.proxyssl.org``` had the script pop up in the head tag. Given that the proxy sites in question had HTTPS connections, it seems unlikely that this is limited to my ISP alone. But if that's true, then I wonder what's causing it to inject itself into every HTTP connection...

EDIT: ... Waterrabbit, would you be willing to install and addon and see if you get the same result? I think an addon called Location Guard is doing this, given that HTTPS connections are getting the same script just inside the head tag

Link to addon: ```https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/location-guard/```

I swear, if I got myself worked up into a panic over this I am going to be peeved.

EDIT 2: ... Yes. Yes it is. Looking at the GitHub repo for the addon, it shows exactly what I was looking for. Apologies for wasting your time.

1_1CYj7o5iamDZeKZvdSAW4P2aEngmAXb78T.body: The options (enabled by default, of course) of greater care in handling of user's private keys at rest, and a passphrase protection on startup. Right now, they are stored as cleartext. On Windows machines, this is not a good thing, as Window's access controls leave something to be desired, and well, there's always Linux boot flash drives to get around them. Having a public-private keypair system would be best, although that turns the something-you-know into something-you-have , which is not always the best of ideas. File-based encryption of data at rest seems like it would be the best compromise between security and usability, preferably with a switch for that zite's data.

2_1BRSETd8x5XUtHt9jz2e4WdB9rWY1WNfiu.body: WineHQ recently (2017-1-24) released v2.0 of Wine, where they switched to a yearly release model. These releases are not updated as frequently, but are much more stable than the development branch. On the other hand, the development branch will have support for more applications faster than releases. Consider which you require, stability or capability, and pick either release or development. The installation procedures will be different for each. Check out ```https://www.winehq.org/download``` for more information. I personally like speedy updates, so I chose the development channel.

@twiggy: This is the source package. Check for prebuilts under https://www.winehq.org/download under the WineHQ Binary Packages section for Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, Mageia and macOS versions, and Distro Binary Packages for SUSE, Slackware and FreeBSD. If you aren't running one of these distros (Linux Mint has both Debian and Ubuntu parents; it's odd), then you will need to compile the source code yourself.
Wine is not a frontend application. Instead, it is a shim between your unmodified Windows dotexe and your Linux system. More in 3hrs, have stuff to do.

Right then, couple of hours lat but screw it.

Wine is not meant to be run by itself. Instead it's a compatibility layer to translate the system calls from Windows dotexes to Linux ones, and back again on the return trip. Running Wine by itself would be futile, so there's no premade shortcut. Instead, make an empty text document with the ```.desktop``` extension, i.e. ```wine-program.desktop``` following the example set by any that you currently possess on your machine. For example, this will work to start the ZeroNet.sh script:

```[Desktop Entry]
Name=Start Zeronet
Comment=Censorship-resistent internet
Exec=/bin/bash -c "cd /path/to/Zeronet/dir/  && ./ZeroNet.sh"
Icon=/path/to/znet_logo.jpg
Terminal=false
Type=Application
Categories=Network;FileTransfer;```

The ```[Desktop Entry]``` header is required to tell the system to start treating the file like a desktop entry, although due to the standard ```.desktop``` extension some systems can get away with just looking at the filename. Without it, most window managers display a text document icon, and the system opens it as a text document upon doubleclick.

```Name=...``` is the displayed name of the shortcut when it is rendered by your window manager. Note that this does not change the filename; if you are interacting with it via the shell, you will need to specify whatever you saved it as, not what the line reads.

```Exec=...``` is the command line that runs your given application. This example would navigate to ```/path/to/Zeronet/dir/``` and, if the directory exists, run the executable script or binary named ```ZeroNet.sh``` in the current directory. I prefer this way because it makes the ```$PWD``` environment variable be passed to the script's shell, preventing some bugs that can be difficult to track down.

```Icon=...``` is the path and filename to the image file displayed by the shortcut. Depending on your system, it may only support jpegs, so be sure to convert if you are uncertain.

```Type=...``` tells the system to open it as this MIME type. Typically, this will be Application.

```Terminal=...``` tells the system to spawn or not spawn a terminal window when running the application via this shortcut. Typically, when running an application via the GUI, one doesn't want a popup :P

Categories and Comments are typically optional. For more information, try the following two links:
```https://help.ubuntu.com/community/UnityLaunchersAndDesktopFiles```
```https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/```

So let's try this with a Windows app under Wine. Wine is special, since by default its desktop files reference the wineprefix's emulated Windows filesystem. Try the following Exec=... line:
```Exec=env WINEPREFIX=/home/<insert username here>/.wine/ wine C:\\\\windows\\\\command\\\\start.exe C:\\\\path\\\\to\\\\exe\\\\file\\\\in\\\\wineprefix``` assuming that the dotexe is located (or even symlinked >:)) to a file in the wineprefix. This sets the environment variable ```WINEPREFIX```to the root of the wineprefix, which is required and will be created/populated if not extant, tells Wine to start the Windows program starter, which then starts the file specified.

For troubleshooting, first ensure you have permissions to execute both the ```.desktop``` file and the dotexe.

If you have any questions, feel free to ask.

> [twiggy](#comment_15_1BRSETd8x5XUtHt9jz2e4WdB9rWY1WNfiu): snip
A: That line is placed in the ```.desktop``` document, not directly into the command terminal. As an aside, you'll need to use four backslashes, since under the hood you are passing the command through two passes of the command processor.

B: NEVER run Wine as root. That will give any maliciously-infected Windows executable root access to your system, leading to Bad Things (tm).

C: Making a ```.desktop``` file is the standard way of starting applications via the GUI. On Ubuntu, ordinary ```apt-get``` installs automatically do this by copying a prebuilt to ```/usr/share/applications``` folder, where they show up in the Unity Dash searchbox. Try the ```gnome-panel``` package, and the ```gnome-desktop-item-edit``` tool. This will be the only time you need to interact with the command line, assuming you plan ahead and create a new dotdesktop file to create new dotdesktop files :P
	1: Open a terminal and install the ```gnome-panel``` package with the following command line:
		```sudo apt-get install gnome-panel --no-install-recommends```
	2: Execute the following to open the GUI, while creating a new dotdesktop:
		```/usr/bin/gnome-desktop-item-edit /home/$USER/Desktop/ --create-new```
	This functions because it is invoking the program, then the first argument says to place this new dotdesktop file in the directory specifed (feel free to replace the $USER with the name of your user, since the command is being invoked by your terminal, it will expand to whatever the ```USER``` environment variable is for that particular shell, can cause problems if you have a nonstandard shell) 
	3: At the GUI, you will see an icon on the left, and a few fields. Click the icon to bring up a file picker and navigate to whatever icon you want displayed. 
	4: Type should remain Application. Name will be whatever you want displayed by your window manager. Comment can be ignored, but may be useful if you ever come back to edit it and forget what the dotdesktop is for :P
	5: Finally, onto the Command field. This is what the ```Exec=...``` line is mapped to. Wine is special in that you will need to prefix the Linux location of the Windows executable with some arguments in order to make it work. For this example, I will be using ```/home/rythyrix/Desktop/catplanet.exe``` as the Windows executable I want to invoke.
	6: Obtain the Linux path of the executable to invoke, and the wineprefix you want to use as the root of the Windows system. In this case, ```/home/rythyrix/.wine/```
	7: Open a text editor, as it's easier to just copy/paste into the Command box of the Create Launcher GUI. Keep in mind that the dotdesktop file will not create
	8: Assemble the line as follows: ```env WINEPREFIX="<your wineprefix here>" wine C:\\windows\\command\\start.exe /Unix "<your Linux executable path here, with no expansions>"``` For example, my line would be ```env WINEPREFIX="/home/rythyrix/.wine/" wine C:\\windows\\command\\start.exe /Unix "/home/rythyrix/Desktop/catplanet.exe"```
	9: Copy/paste the completed command line into the Command box, then click OK. If all went well, you should now have a new dotdesktop on your desktop. Double-click  on it to test if it works.
	10: To make a dotdesktop to make new dotdesktops on your desktop (what a mouthful), place the following command line in the Command box: ```/usr/bin/gnome-desktop-item-edit /home/<your username here>/Desktop --create-new```, adjust Name/Icon as desired, and click OK. Keep in mind you cannot use environment/tilde expansion in the Command box, so you need to type the path without such expansions.
	11: If you are ever interested in learning the command line, this is a good place to start: ```http://www.linuxcommand.org/index.php```

Questions still welcome.

Considering that that's my username, you may wish to replace it with your own. It's a file path pointing to the wineprefix location on your file tree, which the windows logic sees as its root directory. Makes it easy to remove Wine installs; delete the prefix, done. By default, Wine creates a ```.wine``` directory under the given user's home directory. To fix, use your computer's login in place of USER: ```/home/USER/.wine```

First, determine where in your file system the unmodified Windows exe is located. If it's located on your desktop, it will be under ```/home/bob/Desktop/program.exe``` . If you have an inkling of what the filename is, try this oneliner in the command terminal: ```find / -iname *.exe 2>/dev/null | grep -i -e "<filename of exe here>"``` to print where the program is. This will search your entire computer, so it may take a while. Grab a coffee.

In addition, ensure that the ```C:\windows\command\start.exe``` has doubled backslashes (``` \\ ```), because the final shortcut file will need four backslashes to function properly, and each one backslash will be doubled by the GUI.

...Why would you install Wine without a program that you needed to run? Serious question here. Wine does nothing by itself. One thing you could do is navigate to where you are storing said EXE, if you know where it is, and then right click on some empty space in your file manager, there should be something akin to 'Open in Terminal' on the context menu.

Regardless, feel free to zmail me with questions, this is getting crowded and quicker response times may be what you need.

Given that I have no idea what the file structure is inside that split archive, you may be best served by creating a new directory and extracting each into there one at a time. That should emulate the split archive functionality of your archive manager, if it isn't supported. Try googling for Linux archive managers, most should support split RARs out of the box if yours doesn't. Alternatively, you may just not have all of them :P I haven't actually dealt with split archives lately, so take it with a grain of salt. Or the parts may just be individual RARs that happen to contain the seven parts of that game, in which the intended behavior is to extract them all on top of each other. Really depends on the packager.

export WINEPREFIX=<your wineprefix here>
export WINEARCH=win32
cd <directory where the exe is stored>
wine ./<your exe here>


Try that.

You have a space in the file path. Make sure to surround any arguments that contain spaces with doublequotes, or escape each one with a backslash. Quoting in bash is its own !!!FUN!!! thing.

> [twiggy](#comment_45_1BRSETd8x5XUtHt9jz2e4WdB9rWY1WNfiu): ZeroMail needs a feature where people can send pdf files and maybe a few pictures.

Considering that people zmail chatting will typically trust one another a bit more than a message board, consider setting up a ZeroMux dropbox that waterrabbit was working on. Here's a link to the blog post explaining it ```http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/?Post:6:ZeroMux+Dropbox```; in summary, set up your own zite and share the address with those you wish to exchange files with, and you now how a means of transferring the files through ZeroNet without bogging down non-participants with your encrypted cat photos. Alternatively, use Onionshare along with the Tor Browser to transfer, but that's also a bit of a pain and requires installation of other software, instead of being contained within ZeroNet.

1_1HJugahAiT2RnwJQdHuEd2RgW5fpWwNxnB.body:
As shiny and awesome as ZeroNet is, theres a couple of flaws inherent in its design that prevents many people from adopting it: it requires a daemon, and it has remote disk modification capabilities.

Less technically-savvy users don't want to install something that isn't a pretty installer with a wizard and everything; more technically-savvy users don't want the large, LARGE attack surface ZeroNet represents.

I've mitigated the attack surface factor a little by mountbinding my ZeroNet/data directory with fmask 117 and running the daemon as a user with only one group, but both of those require Linux, which represents about 2% of all desktop users. Windows is still king of desktopland.

Point is, there's a lot of work and polish left to do before ZeroNet can possibly get enough users to compete with a centralized service provider; kind of a chicken-and-egg scenario. Market penetration in the modern internet is a bit of a pain.

1_1QEeAynSzdEKo9DZnFJccGBwSS33mZedpz.body: If you run multiple instances of ZeroNet, make sure to publish one set of modifications and receive them on the other device(s) before publishing on any others. Since you publish whatever one instance has, if they aren't synced then you will lose data.

Can I risk myself or my friends and family being discriminated against for a wayward click? Call your reps and tell them that this bullshit is unacceptable.

8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj.body:
> [border0464fred](#comment_78_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6): snip
Try ```trackers = ['protocol://url','another://tracker']``` 
Make sure to include the punctuation, as this is a json array.

You can find the source under ZeroNet/src/Config.py with the lines labeled ```self.parser.add_argument```. The scheme used in zeronet.conf is ```option-name = option-value```, one per line, do not include the double dashes like you would at the command line.

> [akito](#comment_18_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): I have two issues: [...]

Regarding favorited sites, ZeroNet stores your favorite zites as a JSON object inside your browser's local storage. According to [this Superuser post](https://superuser.com/questions/629525/how-to-control-websites-use-of-localstorage-in-firefox#771799), Firefox's cookie and local storage permissions are linked. First, check if your cookies are allowed for ```127.0.0.1``` and/or ```localhost``` and not wiped between closing all tabs/the window (hello, Self-Destructing Cookies addon, fancy seeing you here). This should fix the issue, but I've never experienced the problem, so YMMV.

Regarding the default browser, ZeroNet exposes the option of which to use via the command line option ```--open_browser [path_to_browser_as_one_argument]```. If not specified, assumes the OS's default. If you want to not start with a browser, you'll need to edit either your shortcut or sh/cmd file to not have that argument, or change the ```zeronet.conf``` file to do the same.

> [akito](#comment_20_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): Thank you, very helpful.By now I have another additional problem: some sites tell me e.g. "1 File update failed!". How do I fix this?

That's simply the fact that none of your peers you have connected (connected, not available, there's a difference) have that file, or the file was corrupted en route, or the peer sent a file with the wrong sum. Could be a number of things. Go to the zite that has that error, and drag the purple 0 at the top right leftward. Scroll down to 'Missing Files' and see what file it is. Chances are high it's a user's file, i.e. starting with ```data/users/``` and no one has a correctly signed or summed copy. It happens, and as your connections refresh or swap between your peers, it should resolve itself unless zero people have valid copies.

> [border0464fred](#comment_151_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6): I just realised my content.json is full of sha512 signatures of inexisting files.  [...]

I am actually against this; forcing resumming of each file, even optional, forces two things: A) your node must have all content on the site in order to sum it, and B) doing so takes a comparatively long time, resulting in long sum times per sign, restricting the practical size of zites. Not resumming optional files enables zites to quickly publish new content. On the other hand, when one signs their zite, how does the parser tell not to resum? Timestamp checking, whilst useful, can be defeated with a simple ```touch -t $(date -d @UNIX_EPOCH_SECONDS +%y%m%d%H%m.%S) FILE```. Perhaps a pregex or a seperate json file, in a similar vein to the current model for user content rules?

> [torezen](#comment_4_127xneP1vvFJyc6SQZNzh2hyrkBuezpcvr): [snip]

Depends, there doesn't seem to be a GUI for it, but each site's sent/received byte count is stored under ```ZeroNet/data/sites.json```. Total them all, and there's your values.

> [border0464fred](#comment_152_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6): [snip]

Usecase? I think any time the node you are on doesn't have the content to sum. Hard drive failure comes to mind, or sudden power failure during write to FDE-encrypted drive. While this can be worked around if your zite was popular enough, lesser-known zites with lots of optional files may not have any other option.

Plus, as mentioned, including many optional files increases the sum time per signing, and inflates the size of ```content.json```. This limits the practical size of zites significantly, although with compression support and specialization of zites ala @Kaffie's Kaffiene, this can be mitigated.

> [border0464fred](#comment_153_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6):  [...]
I run multiple nodes (phone, tablet, laptop, desktop) as the same user, so I'm probably in the minority.

Regarding missing files and said hashes, I'm not disputing that the hashes should be rejected by default. Rather, I would like the option to disable the re-hashing of already-registered files, to cut down on sign times and to prevent data loss. Since the signing node's copy overwrites all peer's copies, rather than merge, it's possible that you could overwrite some files peers wish to keep. I'll admit it's not a likely scenario now, but in a future where ZeroNet is the standard, zite operators, especially commercial ones where remote admin is commonplace, would benefit from the ability to recover from any drive failure, so long as the private key was recovered.

I agree that ```content.json``` should not count towards zite limit, but should count toward total ZeroNet space limit.

> [akito](#comment_41_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): How do you run Zeronet on the phone?

Check out the lovely @mkg20001's [tutorial and prebuilt APKs](https://github.com/mkg20001/ZeroNet-kivy). The prebuilt isn't secure for private keys or other sensitive data, at least not without root access and mountbinds, due to exposing the data directory and therefore users.json to USB file transfers (MTP). :( If you can, root your phone, not like OEMs will honor warranties anyway.

> [akito](#comment_42_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): In my country we have warranties that are enforced by law. I don't live in a third world country, like USA is one. (No healthcare system = no first world country)

Snark damage! Also, check your zmail.

> [zer0surfer](#comment_4_15j9RixaGozV6Dwp3a9iigZNbjtUyz6Rbq): mhh I'd rather go with whonix. [...]

Looking at the all.js under ZeroID, line 886 begins a function to send a https POST request to ```https://demo.zeronet.io/ZeroID/request.php```. Without your browser configured to use either a proxy or Tor, this request will be sent with your clearnet IP in its protocol header, enabling anyone with a packet sniffer on either your or the server's end to see where those packets were sent to/from. While the theoretical adversary cannot read the contents of the packets without breaking the encryption on the https stream, traffic correlation is a thing.

One safe(r) method to register a new ZeroID is to use the Tor Browser in a fresh instance of ZeroNet, unpacked under a different directory, get your new cert, and take the ```users.json``` from that instance of ZeroNet and swap out your old one. Since the private authkeys are stored under the one file, this method will not allow you to post anything under your old ZeroID. ZeroNet does not currently support multiple IDs from the same cert authorizer, so you will want to keep the two separate and swap them out as needed, restarting ZeroNet to swap them.

Remember: ***LOSING ALL COPIES OF YOUR PRIVATE KEY IS PRACTICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO RECOVER FROM***. Make encrypted backups, preferably asymmetrical to make a brute forcer's job that much harder. Of course, asymm has the problem of shifting the responsibility of keeping the private key safe from your ZeroNet keys to your asymm keys, but symmetrical encryption is too easy to brute force; assume your file will be attacked with upwards of 1,000,000,000,000 guesses/sec. Length is has more protection than complexity, after a point. Has to do with [combinatorics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorics)... and I'm rambling.

1_1NmkVyqBJX6a82YQFYkCNgQpE9AWsmeppp.body: Each ID has its own certificate and private key. Your node can use any one of them depending on which certs are accepted by the given zite. Having more than one in a single users.json is no detriment, save perhaps confusion as to which ID you are posting under. However, ZeroNet does not currently support multiple certs by the same signer, so you can't have both alice@zeroid.bit and bob@zeroid.bit. You could have alice@kaffie.bit and alice@zeroid.bit , if you felt so inclined. For now, you'll need to swap out different instances of users.json and restart your ZeroNet daemon to swap IDs that are from the same signer.

1_1CwxK59mAFkKoFhnEw3ZyuHsVSEF2bj76.body:
Hi there! In no particular order:

Try [Important Zites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15Pf9VVuDT8NSWj1qUBh4V89yPmrmzRw6a/) for starters; it has a lot of useful links. Another one would be [Antilibrary](http://127.0.0.1:43110/antilibrary.bit) for all the books ever. [Thunderwave](http://127.0.0.1:43110/thunderwave.bit) is a realtime chat zite, with an encrypted message function too. [Snifferdog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/snifferdog.bit/) is the newest of the (currently) four search engines on ZeroNet, and was based off of [Kaffiene](http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit/).  [0chan](http://127.0.0.1:43110/0chan.bit/) is a chan, obvs. [ZeroMusic](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MusicXkuN2pk5hRdmroeyaCLDJtzTicpB/) is a user-generated music player.

If you aren't adverse to using additional (beta) software, try [Loligod's IPFS video site](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16pz3DbSRyz7D7e3qsxWMq98Z8VztJZN4j/), for which you will need to download and run the IPFS binary. [KopyKate](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1aCq7GiJfUfGZ4GftjYaYbsEngPFzcxvN/) is a WebTorrent video streamer, not unlike YouTube.

5_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6.body:
> [border0464fred](#comment_135_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6): Ye, if thoses seeds could share the seed they know, would have a real decentralised network
Peer Exchange is a thing. It's still not a replacement for trackers, due to the insular outcome; every peer sends every other peer the list of peers they know, but no new peers can connect short of manually editing the file and attempting the connection. If two sets of peers rely only on PEX, and there isn't at least one peer in common between the two sets, then those two sets will never meet. Thus, trackers are still a needed thing. Now, if there was say a zeronet-hosted tracker, there's the problem of updates with them, and naturally, as it is hosted on  ZeroNet, all such information would be public. Also runs into problems of hidden services, due to ZeroNet by default randomizing the onion addresses it uses at each startup, due to regenerating the SSL cert used to encrypt communications.

1_18Kax1M9zrX1cFrYwvfc22uFKBmjbn5atN.body:
Incoming port for what? The GUI to connect to, ie 43110 or the fileserver, 15441? Either way, same idea on command line or line in ```zeronet.conf```

```--ui_port PORT
--fileserver_port PORT``` on the command line when running ZeroNet.sh or ZeroNet.cmd

```ui_port = PORT
fileserver_port PORT``` in ```zeronet.conf```

Command line args override conf file args. Afterwards, restart ZeroNet and it will use the new port.

ZeroHello is the welcome page. You might be thinking of ZeroMe, where you can choose to automatically distribute a given user's new images.

Each zite may or may not define optional files via filename filtering against a regular expression; it is not required. When you flick the switch in the purple 0 sidebar for a given zite labeled 'Download and help distribute all files', you're downloading and seeding all the files that you would ordinarily have to request prior to viewing, saving time when browsing said zite at the cost of additional hard drive space, but helping others obtain the zite as well.

6_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6.body: Peer to Peer will never be zero-rated for consumers; such traffic puts quite a load on a given network. It could be a major point of negotiation between companies, though. Microsoft's Windows Update on Win10 has the option to act as a node supporting others to get infected by Win10 updates. Microsoft also makes Skype, which according to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skype_protocol) is peer-to-peer for user directories and , and direct connections for call data. It is not inconceivable that Microsoft could desire to strike a deal with ${ISP} to zero-rate Skype, giving it a market advantage over other VoIP and video calling applications.

2_1BiouZaoK2zKaqSihxi7LudLqix6ynXYtj.body:
> [thatmexikan](#comment_7_1GxGDmjdgePeraKqV2yQRiRQM4E5rud79R): Should be sent in clear since ZeroNet does not use HTTPS. [...]

ZeroID communicates with a backend to control access to their private key; this request is sent via your browser, so if you use the Tor Browser to get it, that's torified, or your normal browser is tunneling your traffic through a proxy (tor or otherwise). Regarding OP, the question is HOW is your tor enabled? Just the ```tor = enabled``` option in your zeronet.conf? Is your OS of choice forwarding all traffic to the Tor daemon's SOCKS proxy, do you have an external box in between your gateway and your cable/antenna/sat dish/whatever? All of these have differing effects.

2_1DzpF7398yNGjFwHQqHAu9fRkbE3WZ6dZA.body:
The ```--proxy``` option enables ZeroNet to connect via a SOCKS5 proxy, if you need a non-Tor option. Otherwise, try running the Tor Browser, then starting ZeroNet with the following command line options: ```--tor always --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151```. These options can be made permanent; modify your ```ZeroBundle\ZeroNet\zeronet.conf``` file by making a backup, then adding the following lines to it:
```
tor = always
tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9151 
tor_proxy = 127.0.0.1:9150 
```
The scheme for converting command line options to config files options is removing the double - and adding an = in between the option and the value. Make sure to place one option on one line.

3_1DLHbq2nvwpgU4xT3ajhABAW1Lfn3zTZhe.body: Try submitting your site to [New ZeroNet Sites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LtvsjbtQ2tY7SCtCZzC4KhErqEK3bXD4n/). It's a good way to get some initial seeders.

5_1DLHbq2nvwpgU4xT3ajhABAW1Lfn3zTZhe.body: Drop the file in your zite's directory, then sign and publish your changes. Without either an '```optional``` or ```ignore``` object in your zites content.json, all files (except symlinks on GNU/Linux) will be hashed and pushed. Afterwards, add  a link to the file using the Markdown syntax ```[descriptive text](link relative to site root)```. Then finally publish the modified or new blog post.

> [cundhi](#comment_6_18Qsh8ixNQYx8fCLgLVxPGnQgRDwyNk9ZW): Is it too big? Recommended that each file is less than 10M.

Max size TOTAL for a zite is default 10MB; I ran into the max size limit issue, if a file is not classified as optional, it contributes towards the maximum size a zite can be. If you are for some reason adverse to not forcing people to download the PDFs the moment they load your zite, you can force the maximum higher by dragging the purple 0's sidebar open, scrolling down to ```SIZE LIMIT```,  and increasing the size. This will allow ZeroNet to use more data for your zite, but also forces peers to accept a larger size immediately to continue downloading a zite.

I really do recommend using optional files; they make visitors happy by not forcing them to download a file they may not want. To enable it, back up your zite's content.json, then add the following object:
```
...
 "modified": 1496038455,
 "optional": "(big/.*)",
 "sign": [
...
```
replacing 'big' with whatever the folder you want to store optional files in is. ```"optional":``` denotes a [Python regular expression](http://www.regular-expressions.info/) (clearnet), or pregex for short, that if the pregex matches the file path of a given file under your zite's root, it is marked as optional. For example, myNullPaste has the optional object containing ```"(loader/files/.*)"```.  All files that such a pregex matches will be marked as optional. Anything that does not is either ignored (if the ```"ignore":``` object is set) or mandatory. It's considered polite to place large files as optional, and provide links to them to save on other user's disk space; this allows low-space nodes to seed your zite without worrying about running out of disk space. If you truly need another seed for a very large file, consider asking a proxy operator if they are willing to host it as well. Naturally, different users' opinions about what size is considered very large will vary. I personally consider any one file over 25Mb to be required to be optional before I continue seeding; comes from running nodes on Android devices' internal storage.

Visit your ZeroNet address ( 127.0.0.1:43110 for most people ) but instead of entering a zite's public key (address), type ```/Benchmark```. For example, ```http://127.0.0.1:43110/Benchmark```.

1_14nJi66XbVW75K8dVLmXaQixVJ9vt5pcNF.body: Don't forget to backup the users.json to be overwritten; if you've registered a ZeroID with that device, it will be lost forever if you overwrite it by copying over it with the second machine's users.json.

13_1DLHbq2nvwpgU4xT3ajhABAW1Lfn3zTZhe.body:
Net neutrality requires that no matter what the data traveling across their network is, ISPs must treat it the same as any other data. Bandwidth restrictions on P2P protocols (BitTorrent especially) have been throttled before, and the removal of the Open Internet Order's teeth would allow ISPs to fuck with your Internet connection to *incentivize* you to pay pay-TV prices for DSL speeds. Not content with charging more for the same speed, ISPs could also charge for access to specific sites, such as Netflix and Google, or they could simply block all Tor traffic legally and there goes one private Internet. Or block all banking sites unless they pony up another fee, which will be passed along to you, the customer.

In regards to ZeroNet, it's P2P, which ISPs have a monetary incentive to throttle in the form of bribes from wrongsholders, greater bandwidth availability to higher-paying customers and further siloization and vendor lock-in with existing customers.

Take the cable box probably sitting on your television vanity; a proprietary black box you get charged out the nose to have to offer one-tenth the utility of an Internet connection. Without net neutrality, the ISPs who own the last ~30 feet of wire to your home would be able to filter, spoof, hijack and modify all the traffic in your connection to present the side of a political story influencing you to vote whatever way they want, or simply stop your post on a given issue from ever reaching anyone else, censoring your opinion at the whim of whomever pays them the most money that hour.

In summary, net neutrality is **rather important** to the continued freedom of expression one enjoys online, and is the lifeblood of P2P projects everywhere, including ZeroNet. So yes, the erosion Matters.

1_18JuREUrfUPwdwJLPA336tSjVaap8VSZp4.body:
> [elspru](#comment_11_1A3XsuLB6P7LQPCw1QWASG7RGSwrCv6Xib): [snip]

Okay. That creates a chilling effect where unknown sites won't receive new peers, keeping them stillborn and centralizing everyone to the standard zites all over again. How would you determine, before you go there, whether a site is dangerous or not?

1_1FjjwJVBfwkjrW2sgeH1Rrmms5ecWHAhTd.body:
> [eliteotaku](#comment_1_1P15txe9zod4HLQTMbuNp485Q9AyZWoKN): don't worry, even there are, they won't get you because everything here is anonymous.

Pseudonymous. If you're connecting via clearnet, or using Tor-only mode but not using a browser configured to route all traffic through Tor, then it is fairly easy to suss out who a given IP addr is. ZN assigns a peer ID to itself whenever a non-Tor connection is solicited.

There are ways to completely isolate oneself from any clearnet monitoring entity, mostly thru Tor. But of course, best practice is to simply never type anything personal in ZN to begin with.

1_1NJPghRQFKLo3CdjKw1pLcFNHhqAUnUQsZ.body: [Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Lj1oPcN7oZQL8HkS5KbkzQuKqs42zQWY6] you go. Ordinarily I would point you to a search engine, but a ZaroNet update has broken lots of their functionality.

1_1N1bEAsjdqCy5f7SG6jPXUoa1BA2QES8DZ.body: Be sure to encrypt it before moving it off-device. The traces left after deleting a file can still be recovered with file scapel software like PhotoRec, so it's best to never write the file to disk unencrypted in the first place.

15_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body: crontab or Scheduled Task for backing up your own files is a good idea.
